metadata.title: Phonotrauma, Pediatric -Videostroboscopic examination (rigid and flexible): Videostroboscopic examination allows the examiner to see the vocal folds vibrating in slow motion and provides information on any abnormalities present during voice production (e.g., abnormal closure). It is performed with instrumentation used for oral endoscopy or nasendoscopy and is combined with a strobe light correlated to vocal fold vibration(17,18) -Electroglottography: Electroglottography provides information on vocal fold closure by measuring the electrical resistance of two electrodes placed around the neck(17) –Reading and writing:  If concerns about reading and/or writing are present, use formal and informal measures to assess •Oral structure and oral motor function:  Conduct an assessment of the patient’s oral motor structures and functions •Swallow examination:  Screen swallowing ability; if there are concerns regarding dysphagia and aspiration as a result of phonotrauma, complete a full swallowing examination –For detailed information on treatment of dysphagia in childhood, see Clinical Review…Dysphagia in Childhood ; CINAHL Topic ID Number: T708938 –For detailed information on a clinical swallow examination (CSE) for pediatric patients, see Clinical Review…Dysphagia Assessment: In-depth  Bedside Swallow Examination (Pediatrics) ; CINAHL Topic ID Number: T709064 –For detailed information on modified barium swallow studies for pediatric patients, see Clinical Review…Dysphagia Assessment: Modified Barium Swallow (Pediatrics) ; CINAHL Topic ID Number: T709077 •Tracheostomy examination:  If present, assess tracheostomy tube and document date of placement, current respiratory status, and use of speaking valve. For detailed information on assessment of tracheostomy tube and use of a speaking valve, see Clinical Review…Passy-Muir  Tracheostomy & Ventilator Swallowing and Speaking Valve ; CINAHL Topic ID Number: T708919. For detailed information on assessment of children with tracheostomies, see Clinical Review…Dysphagia: Children with Tracheostomy ; CINAHL Topic ID Number: T709082 Assessment/Plan of Care
area of specialty: v oice and v oice disorders

ICD-10 codes.R49.8: other and unspecified voice disturbances (ICD codes are provided for the reader’s reference, not for billing purposes)

reimbursement: Reimbursement for therapy will depend on insurance contract coverage; no specific issues or information regarding reimbursement has been identified
presentation signs and symptoms: Phonotrauma describes trauma to the vocal mechanism that can result from abusive vocal behaviors that include yelling, screaming, excessive throat-clearing,  and sounds produced during play (e.g., animal sounds, baby sounds).(1,2) Trauma to the vocal folds can lead to the loss of voice, hoarseness, abnormal pitch, and inflamed vocal fold mucosa.(1,3) Over a prolonged period of time, a localized lesion may form, most commonly at the midpoint of the vibratory margin of one or both of the membranous vocal folds.(3) V ocal lesions include nodules, polyps and cysts, fibrous masses, and reactive lesions(3)

The following symptoms have been noted in children with phonotrauma: –A “lump in the throat” sensation(4) –A change in vocal pitch (usually a deepening of the voice)(5) –Breathlessness while speaking(5) –Decreased pitch range(4) –Excessive coughing or throat clearing(5) –Excessively loud voice(5) –Neck pain(4) –Persistent dry or sore throat(5) –Persistent hoarseness or huskiness(5) –Strain or discomfort while speaking(5) –V oice breaks (periods of aphonia)(5) –Weak or breathy voice(5) Causes, Pathogenesis, & Risk Factors
contraindications precautions to test: Routine otorhinolaryngological and laryngovideostroboscopic examinations (performed by an ENT) typically are conducted prior to referral for speech-language  services

risk factors: Environment (more common in children who live in urban areas)(5)

overall contraindications precautions: Precautions will vary according to the individual patient. A child’s medical records should be thoroughly reviewed prior to evaluation or treatment. During the evaluation, it is important to be aware of a child’s level of fatigue, pain tolerance, and level of frustration. A patient’s culture and native language should also be considered to determine the appropriateness of examination and treatment materials(10)

Unlike most adults with voice disorders, a child might not have a memory or internal representation of a “normal voice” or healthy vocal habits and may be less motivated to change.(2) However, many children are aware of their voice differences and can have associated anger, frustration, or sadness.(11) It is important to include parents/caregivers in the evaluation and treatment process

history of present illness.mechanism of injury or etiology of illne: Document age at onset of symptoms of phonotrauma (for how long has the patient been experiencing symptoms?). Refer to medical records for information on severity and etiology

course of treatment.medical management: Document any medical examinations from physicians, such as an otolaryngologist. Document any medical management for other conditions (e.g., respiratory infections, cerebral palsy, sinus or tonsillar infections)(12)
course of treatment.medications: Determine what medications the physician has prescribed; are they being taken? Oral corticosteroids often are prescribed for the treatment of acute vocal fold inflammation associated with phonotrauma(24) Evidence supports the use of oral steroids for acute vocal fold inflammation associated with phonotrauma in adult patients; however, there is no published research on the effects of oral steroids on phonotrauma in children(24)
diagnostic tests completed: Diagnostic tests completed:  Usual tests for this condition are the following:
course of treatment.alternative therapies: Document any use of home remedies or alternative therapies and whether they help
course of treatment.previous therapy: Document whether patient has had speech, occupational, physical, or psychological therapy for this or other conditions and what specific treatments were helpful or not helpful

history of present illness.aggravating easing factors: Document times of day at which the child’s voice is better or worse. Note environmental factors that influence vocal use and abuse (e.g., school, playground, background noise)
history of present illness.nature of symptoms: Document the nature of symptoms associated with the phonotrauma as reported by the patient and/or parent/caregiver; also document subjective descriptions (e.g., hoarse, breathy, strained) as observed by the speech-language  pathologist (SLP) during the evaluation -Use a visual analog scale (V AS) to report the patient’s subjective complaint of pain
history of present illness.other symptoms: Document other symptoms patient may be experiencing that could exacerbate the condition and/ or symptoms that could be indicative of a need to refer to physician (e.g., hearing impairment, gastric reflux, cold/flu/ allergies/asthma)Document any behavioral symptoms that could indicate psychosocial disturbances -Many children are aware of their voice differences and experience associated anger, frustration, or sadness(11) -Identify any excessive stress or tension in the child’s life that could cause or exacerbate hyperfunctional voice use (e.g., recent changes such as divorce, death, moving, or other family experiences)(12)Quality of life measures have been found to reflect significant impairment in social-emotional  and(13)A 10-item  validated pediatric voice outcomes instrument(14)A 23-item  outcome measure for pediatric patients based on the VHI(15)Document hearing ability, including history of hearing loss, ear infections, or ear tubes Barriers to learning -Are there any barriers to learning? Yes__ No__ -If Yes, describe ____________________________

past medical history.previous history of same similar diagnos: Does the patient have a history of speech and/or language difficulties? Has the child ever had a voice disturbance?
past medical history.comorbid diagnoses: Ask patient or parent/caregiver about other medical diagnoses that could affect the patient’s voice or respiratory system (e.g., allergies, hearing impairment)
past medical history.medications previously prescribed: Obtain a comprehensive list of medications prescribed and/or being taken (including OTC drugs)
past medical history.other symptoms: Ask child or child’s family about other symptoms the child is experiencing

social and occupational history.vocation avocation and associated repeti: Does the child participate in any hobbies or sports that require talking, yelling, or singing? If the child sings in an organized group, inquire about amount of participation and singing role
social and occupational history.functional limitations assistance with A: How does the voice disorder affect functional communication? Does the child wear hearing aids?
social and occupational history.living environment: Identify the child’s living situation and the potential communication difficulties that the child may be experiencing at home. Does the house have excessive background noise (e.g., television, music, siblings)? Do other family members talk loudly or have voice difficulties? Does any member of the family have a hearing impairment?(12)

relevant tests and measures.general: (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be ›Relevant tests and measures: (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be appropriate to patient medical condition, functional status, and setting) •Audiological screening/evaluation:  Conduct a hearing screening to rule out hearing loss as a cause of hyperphonia (excessive effort in voice production)
relevant tests and measures.speech and language examination: Speech and language (including reading)Identify any articulation or fluency concerns(10)Identify any receptive or expressive language concerns(10)In children with voice disorders, identify the voice’s perceptual and acoustic characteristics (if child is able to phonate) and the child’s physiological behavior (e.g., strained, effortful) during voicing or voicing attempts. Perceptual and/or instrumental measures can be completed in order to obtain perceptual ratings, acoustic analysis, and/or aerodynamic measures(10)A laryngeal examination must be completed by an experienced otolaryngologist in order to detect the presence of any laryngeal growths such as nodules, polyps, carcinoma, contact ulcers, or laryngeal webs. In addition, the laryngeal examination serves to determine the position of the larynx (e.g., high, low) and any other characteristics of the vocal folds, including vocal fold closure and physical aspects of the folds (e.g., swollen, tense). Patient should be referred for a follow-up  biopsy if a growth is identified.(10) Laryngeal examinations involve any or allA mirror examination involves placing a mirror in the back of the throat of the patient. V ocal folds can be visualized by reflecting light down to the voice box(16)A flexible laryngoscope is preferred over a rigid laryngoscope because it is better tolerated by children who have sensitive gag reflexes. A flexible laryngoscope uses fiberoptic technology and can be passed through the nose to the back of the throat to allow for examination of the larynx during voicing.(17,18) The flexible scope used for a child is smaller than those used for adults.(5) The examination typically is performed by an otolaryngologist or a specially trained SLP. The SLP can prepare the child by explaining the

contraindications precautions.general: Patients must receive a thorough medical (laryngeal) examination from an

assessment plan of care.diagnosis need for treatment: Diagnosis of phonotrauma should be made in collaboration between the SLP and otolaryngologist(19)
assessment plan of care.rule out: The patient’s medical team will rule out a neurological or psychosocial disorder.(12) Otolaryngologist should rule out other organic disorders not caused by vocal hyperfunction, such as papilloma, laryngopharyngeal reflux, submucosal cysts, or fractured larynx(20,21)
assessment plan of care.referral to other disciplines: Refer to otolaryngology, psychology, or counseling as appropriate(12)
treatment summary: Treatment summary:  Outcome data remain lacking on the treatment of children with phonotrauma. Therapy approaches include behavior management, vocal hygiene, patient/parent/teacher education, and direct voice therapy.(1) Nodules and polyps may be treated medically or behaviorally, and surgery is rare for children.(4) Behavioral voice therapy is typically the preferred first-line  treatment intervention.(23) Because treatment often involves behavioral change, it is important to have parent and teacher involvement.(2) One of the major challenges in pediatric voice therapy is poor motivation for change and a lack of awareness that change is necessary. Activities that promote understanding of normal vocal function and the disorder are recommended(2) . Problem Goal Intervention Expected Progression Home Program Phonotrauma Child and child’s family will understand the effects of vocal abuseChild and family education: normal voice production and vocal abuse _ The SLP can educate the child (when developmentally appropriate) and family about normal anatomy and physiology of voice production using drawings, video, handouts, and/or props. When possible, the use of videoendoscopic images of the patient’s larynx is useful for conveying information about the physiology and anatomy of the vocal mechanism(12)The child and child’s family will understand basic principles of voice production and the effects of vocal abuse(12)A home program may include educational materials for the parents and child to read together  Phonotrauma and poor ability to discriminate between healthy and unhealthy vocal behaviorsChild and child’s family will better discriminate between healthy and unhealthy vocal behaviorsDiscrimination training _ The SLP can play audiotaped recordings of the child’s voice and have the child and/or family rate the child’s productions to better discriminate between healthy and unhealthy vocal behaviors.(21) V ocally abusive behaviors include frequent coughing, throat clearing, loud crying, sharp glottal attacks, or grunting. In addition, vocally abusive patterns such as screaming, using excessively strained voices (e.g., “funny” voices associated with characters), singing loudly, or talking over background noise must be eliminated(12)The child and child’s family will better discriminate between healthy and unhealthy vocal behaviorsA home program may include assignments to chart child’s progress with good vocal behaviors at home Phonotrauma and poor vocal hygieneChild and child’s family will understand the importance of hydration for the health of the larynxChild and family education: vocal hygiene _ The SLP can educate the family about the importance of maintaining good vocal hygiene: _ Dehydration requires increased air pressure (subglottic) to initiate vocal fold vibration, resulting in increased tension and strain on the vocal folds. _ Hydration decreases strain/tension on the vocal folds and lowers the risk of edematous (swollen) tissue(1)The child and child’s family will understand and implement principles of good vocal hygiene(12)A home program will include following principles of good vocal hygiene  Phonotrauma Eliminate vocally abusive behaviors by direct therapyDirect voice treatment _ The following is an example of direct voice treatment for phonotrauma: _ Easy onset of voice and resonant (front focused) tone: Make child aware of a sharp glottal attack or tense voice by having him or her feel the difference between rapid onset of initial vowels in words (“air”) as opposed to the more slowly produced /h/ + vowel sequence (“hair”).(12) _ Practice with the / h/ onset should be accompanied by using a front focus (resonant) tone. To make the child aware of front focus resonance, have the child use techniques such as blowing bubbles while voicing, blowing into a straw (with a cup of water) while voicing, using a kazoo, or making raspberries. The child should use front focus resonance and easy onsets in increasingly more complex language tasks (e.g., words, phrases, sentences)(22)The child will learn to use a healthy voice in increasingly complex language tasksV oice exercises should be practiced at home to assist the child in generalizing new behaviors .

desired outcomes of voice therapy for a: The patient will discriminate between healthy versus vocally abusive behaviors(21)
The patient will be able to incorporate appropriate vocal behavior into overall communication behavior(2)

The family and patient will better understand principles of good vocal hygiene (e.g., maintaining adequate hydration,reducing exposure to smoke, eliminating irritants to vocal folds such as acid reflux and pollution, reducing abusivebehaviors such as excessive shouting and throat clearing)

maintenance or prevention: The child might benefit from counseling to maintain the gains achieved in therapy
As part of the therapy process, the child and child’s family should be given education on vocal hygiene to prevent further damage to the voice
Patient and family education should include information about typical vocal processes as well as effects of vocal abuse/ misuse
patient education: See “V ocal Cord Nodules and Polyps” from the American Speech-Language-Hearing Association at https://www.asha.org/public/speech/disorders/V ocal-Cord-Nodules-and-Polyps/
See “Conditions We Treat: Phonotrauma (Cysts, Polyps and Nodules)” at https://www.hopkinsmedicine.org/otolaryngology/ specialty_areas/voice_center/conditions/phonotrauma.html Note

Recent review of the literature has found no updated research evidence on this topic since previous publication on February 10, 2017 Coding Matrix References are rated using the following codes, listed in order of strength: MPublished meta-analysis SRPublished systematic or integrative literature review RCTPublished research (randomized controlled trial) RPublished research (not randomized controlled trial) CCase histories, case studies GPublished guidelinesRVPublished review of the literature RUPublished research utilization report QIPublished quality improvement report LLegislation PGRPublished government report PFRPublished funded reportPPPolicies, procedures, protocols XPractice exemplars, stories, opinions GIGeneral or background information/texts/reports UUnpublished research, reviews, poster presentations or other such materials CPConference proceedings, abstracts, presentation
